dialogOption.texten: 911, what's your emergency?
The chainsaw, I . . . .I just cut my leg. . . And there is nobody here who could help me.
Tell me exactly what happend.
I was just cutting some wood with a chainsaw. Somehow the cainsaw hit my left leg. . . . and now, well you know. . . .there is a lot of blood.
Where did the accident happen?
At the backyard of my house.
I am going to need the address of your house.
When did it happen?
. . . . . . . . Maybe two minutes ago?
{FIRST AID} Alright, I will help you now. First, you have to put your legs in the correct position.
Which position?
{GROUND LEVEL} Just at ground level.
{HIGH} So high, that your legs are higher in the air than your head. This way more blood will flow to your head and you will stay concious.
Ok . . . done.
{GET HELP} Do you see someone who could help you?
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . No, there is just me lying on the ground in my garden.
{DRESS WOUND} Do you have something to dress your wound? A piece of clothing for example?
Well, I got my sweater right here. Can I use it?
Yes. Put it on your wounded leg.
{PRESSURE} Now you have to put pressure on your injury. This way you will lose less blood.
{NO PRESSURE} We don't want too much pressure on your injury, because you would cut of your legs blood circulation.
Alright, I just use my hand.
{WAIT FOR AMBULANCE} OK, now you just have to wait. The ambulance is on their way.
Alright, I just use my hand and try to put as much pressure on the cut as possible.
{PRESSURE + AMBULANCE} The last thing you have to do is to keep the pressure on the wound and wait for the ambulance to arrive.
How long do you think it will take them?
Less than 2 minutes.
Less than 5 minutes.
{ADRESS} I just need your adress to send them to you.
10 Minutes.
I hope you are right, because I feel like I . . .
Maybe you should have asked that question at the beginning? I am at . . .
I hope they are faster than that, because I . . . .
I.. I... everything is going bla... . . . . . . . . . . . .
Sure. . . .
